awd_titl_txt: Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining STEM Pedagogies Using Mixed-Reality Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by developing undergraduate STEM education students’ ability to teach in a way that is culturally and linguistically sustaining through a learning model that includes practicing teaching with virtual avatars. While the number of students who speak a language other than English at home continues to grow, English Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL) students have persistently floundered in K-12 schools and are underrepresented particularly in STEM fields in both college and the workforce. Most STEM teachers in the United States have received only limited preparation in ESOL instruction. Therefore, it is critical to prepare STEM pre-service teachers to better serve students who do not speak English as their primary language. This project provides online modules to develop culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM pedagogies with focused mentor feedback and high-quality mixed-reality simulation practices throughout the learning sequence. Anticipated outcomes of this project are the improvement of undergraduate students’ ability to enact culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM pedagogies as they support learning of students who speak another language than English at home, as well as the development of effective practice-based teacher education learning experiences including replicable online instructional activities.

Project goals include 1) developing undergraduate STEM education students’ culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM teaching practices and 2) understanding effects of an online learning model with mixed-reality simulations on their improvement of culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM teaching. This project uses a mixed-methods research design. Developing instructional expertise requires not only learning knowledge and observing exemplary teaching but also purposeful practices with critical reflection and focused feedback. Compared to a typical teacher education program in which pre-service teachers learn the knowledge and concepts in their coursework and experience actual teaching toward exiting the program, the experiential learning model provides "experience" in the very beginning so that STEM pre-service teachers can recognize their existing practices, proceed through purposeful learning, and develop more effective concept building. Multilingual avatars are included in the mathematics and science simulations developed through this project. In addition, embedding multiple mixed-reality simulation opportunities with focused mentor feedback provides high-quality practice opportunities purposefully distributed throughout the pre-service teachers program of study. The mixed-reality simulations with mentoring are designed to provide the pre-service STEM teachers with opportunities to practice pedagogies that attend to the multi-layered conceptualization of language demands in STEM and learners' buy-in regarding incorporation of culture as well as complex implementation skill development. Results of this project are to be disseminated through professional avenues (i.e., national and local conferences and peer-reviewed journals), the NSF STEM for All video showcase, and a program website. The project has the potential to benefit the STEM education community by preparing STEM teachers for multicultural and multilingual classrooms, which will eventually improve educational equity for all students. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.  Partial funding is from the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Project entitled, Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining STEM Pedagogies Using Mixed-reality Simulations, at the University of West Florida developed undergraduate Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education students' teaching methods that support students' cultures and languages in STEM classrooms through a practice-based learning cycle. Over the course of one and a half years, over 50 undergraduate STEM education students (hereafter pre-service teachers) participated in a learning cycle approximately two months long to develop critical teaching methods to work with multilingual learners, who are often marginalized in STEM classrooms.

The comprehensive practice-based learning cycle consisted of three platforms. First, the participating pre-service teachers engaged in online lessons to learn teaching methods that support students' cultures and languages in STEM classrooms. The online lessons are grounded in Language-based Approach to Content Instruction (LACI)'s six Cs of support for scaffolding for multilingual learners, which are comprised of connection, culture, code-breaking, challenge, community and collaboration, and classroom interactions (de Oliveira, 2023). This framework is adapted to be STEM specific for this project. The research team developed four learning modules in Canvas as well as a four-scale assessment rubric, Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining STEM Pedagogies Rubric, to guide pre-service teachers' lesson planning and reflection and evaluate their simulation teaching. Second, the pre-service teachers engaged in multiple mixed-reality teaching simulations in the online Avatar Lab. These simulations were purposefully distributed following a practice-based learning cycle based on an experiential learning framework (Kolb, 1984) initially and an adapted SHIFT cycle (Safe & Stengle, 2020) later. The pre-service teachers taught a science lesson to avatar students using various teaching methods in a supportive, low-risk STEM environment. Third, they engaged in a video assessment platform to critically analyze their own teaching and reflected on a mentor's feedback as they directly marked and commented on their teaching videos. 

This project yielded positive outcomes regarding the participating pre-service teachers' confidence and teaching practices. The analysis of self-reflective surveys, rubric scores assessed by external scorers, and focus group interviews show that the pre-service teachers felt more confident and comfortable in working with multilingual learners and enhanced their teaching in all six areas of culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM pedagogies. They also commented that the opportunities to teach the same lesson multiple times with different foci and receive a mentor's detailed feedback were significant in improving their lessons.

The research team has disseminated the progress and achievements of this project in multiple venues, including nine conference presentations (two regional, three national, and four international), one book chapter (Kim et al., 2024), and one blog post (Lew et al., in press). Four manuscripts are currently in progress. The online module content as well as assessment rubric for the development of culturally and linguistically sustaining STEM pedagogies will be shared through Canvas and provide a model infrastructure to STEM teacher educators.

Mixed-reality simulations are highly appealing tools and provide engaging and authentic practice opportunities to prepare pre-service teachers for real classrooms. Also, video assessment is beneficial to assist pre-service teachers in analyzing how they enacted what they had planned and in critically reviewing and responding to mentor's feedback. This technology rich learning cycle leads pre-service teachers to make the most use of these opportunities. This cycle can be widely applied to pre-service teacher education and in-service professional development across disciplines. In addition, the four-scale Culturally and Linguistically Sustaining STEM Pedagogies Rubric that the research team developed to guide and assess teaching methods that support students' cultures and languages in STEM classrooms will contribute to both multilingual learner education and STEM education fields. 

This project will further contribute to developing more culturally and linguistically competent STEM teachers and improving the STEM achievement and occupational aspiration of multilingual learners, which will eventually lead to more equitable STEM education for all. In addition, given the high economic value of STEM jobs, the long-term impact of this study will contribute to improving multilingual learners' economic potentials by opening doors for success in STEM careers (National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine [NASEM], 2018). At the same time, given the high demands in STEM career paths, diversifying the STEM workforce will be beneficial to society in general─and to STEM fields in particular─since a diverse workforce can bring unique perspectives to solve various issues in STEM fields (NASEM, 2018).
